properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat wave is expected this week. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will persist over the next few days. The heat wave will move to settle north of Montreal beginning Tuesday. Temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and will not fall below 18 degrees at night. Combined values of the temperature and the humidity will give a humidex value of 40. These conditions may persist into Friday. During times of high heat, your health and the health of your family and friends can deteriorate rapidly. The ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux du Québec, in cooperation with Environment and Climate Change Canada, recommends that you protect yourself from the effects of the heat by taking the following actions: Drink 6 to 8 glasses of water per day. As appropriate, follow your physician's instructions regarding the amount of fluid to drink; Avoid alcoholic beverages; Spend at least 2 hours a day in an air conditioned or cool place; Take at least one cool shower or bath per day, or cool your skin several times per day with wet towels; Limit physical activity; Wear light clothes. Be sure to: Never leave a child or a baby alone in a vehicle or a poorly ventilated room, even for a few minutes; Check on your loved ones, especially those who are vulnerable or living alone. If you have any questions regarding your health, call Info-Santé by dialing 8-1-1 or ask a health care provider. In case of emergency, call 9-1-1. For more information, visit the Government of Quebec's Portail santé mieux-être at www.sante.gouv.qc.ca. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-07T17:30:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-07T01:31:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0729133508.2020
Area: Gatineau
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues tonight. Low temperatures will range from 16 to 18 degrees Celsius tonight. Although daily high temperatures will continue reaching near 29 degrees Celsius for much of the week, Heat Warning criteria is not expected to be met due to the relief provided by cooler overnight lows. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-07T17:42:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-07T01:43:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1758504307.2020
Area: Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather will continue through the rest of this week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 31 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected this week. Overnight lows near or in excess of 21 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. A slightly cooler airmass may move into the area this weekend, however there is considerable uncertainty. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-07T17:39:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-07T01:40:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1501063103.2020
Area: Chatham-Kent - Rondeau Park, Windsor - Leamington - Essex County

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An oppressive heat wave is expected this week. A warm and humid air mass over Southern Quebec will continue over the next few days. Beginning Tuesday, temperatures will exceed the 30-degree mark during the day and will not fall below 20 degrees at night. The combined temperature and humidity values will give humidex values of 40. These conditions may last into Friday. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heat event continues through the end of the week. Inland from the Great Lakes, daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius will accompany humidex values in the low to mid thirties through the next several days. Overnight low temperatures in the mid to upper teens are also expected during this period. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. Never leave people or pets inside a parked vehicle. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing quarter-sized hail and wind gusts in excess of 90 km/h. At 8:40 PM CST Doppler RADAR indicated that this severe thunderstorm was located about 25 km south of Eastend and was moving toward the northeast at 30 km/h. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles.
Expires: 2020-07-07T05:41:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-07T02:43:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3440626365.2020
Area: R.M. of Frontier including Frontier and Claydon

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts and large hail. Hazards: - Damaging wind gusts of 90 to 110 km/h - Nickel to Toonie sized hail Locations: Portions of Northeastern and Far-Northeastern Ontario. Timing: Overnight. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.
Expires: 2020-07-07T08:47:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-07T04:34:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3030636967.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, damaging hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms have developed, and it is possible that some may become severe in the next hour or two. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 1:14 AM EDT weather radar and lightning detector indicated scattered intense thunderstorms capable of producing large hail, locally heavy downpours and damaging wind gusts up to 90 km/h. These storms are located near Moose River and Ranoke and are moving northeast at 50 km/h. Locations impacted include: Tidewater Provincial Park, Moose River, Onakawa, Kesagami Provincial Park, Little Long Rapids, and Smoky Falls, ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-07T07:18:30-00:00
